items.title: Hinterland autocompletes code too fast
items.body:
When typing code quickly, hinterland always will complete my code for me while I'm typing. It forces me to slow down, weather I want the code suggested or not. An example would be something like:

my_variable = 3.4
print(my_variable)

When typing the print statement, if I am typing quickly, hinterland will autocomplete my code so I end up with something like:

print(my_variableariable)

Which I then have to backspace a bunch of times to undo. If I slowdown it will hint but not autocomplete my code. I am not sure how to turn off autocomplete since I would much rather prefer to hit enter if the suggestion matches. I do want hints but due to the unpredictability of when hinterland decides to autocomplete, I want to turn that function off but do not see an option.

items.title: Notebook extension for dyslexic and visual accessibility
items.body:
We are a team of MSc students from UCL working on the accessibility of Jupyter Notebooks. We are looking at creating some extensions which focus on accessibility for people with dyslexia or colour blindness. We are thinking of working on the following five extensions:

1. Text format toolbar - A toolbar which allows users to change the text size, colour, spacing etc. to make the text as readable/accessible as possible for users
2. Code spell checker - Live syntax checking of code as the user types underlining when a syntax error has occurred
3. Voice control - Allow some commonly used functionality such as running a notebook, restarting the kernel etc. be carried out using voice control
4. Planner - a planner that is displayed down the side of a page allowing the user to plan out and write notes about their notebook
5. Accessible themes - various themes such as high contrast which will make the notebook more easily readable

It would be great if anyone could give us some feedback about these ideas and whether they are feasible.

items.title: zenmode not activated by default for read only user
items.body:
Hi guys,

I have installed the following and I'm using python 3.7.2:

```
jupyter                   1.0.0                    py37_7  
jupyter_client            5.2.4                    py37_0  
jupyter_console           6.0.0                    py37_0  
jupyter_contrib_core      0.3.3                      py_2    conda-forge
jupyter_contrib_nbextensions 0.5.1                    py37_0    conda-forge
jupyter_core              4.4.0                    py37_0  
jupyter_highlight_selected_word 0.2.0                 py37_1000    conda-forge
jupyter_latex_envs        1.4.4                 py37_1000    conda-forge
jupyter_nbextensions_configurator 0.4.1                    py37_0    conda-forge
```

I'm starting the jupyter server with a user who has only read access to the file system. Everything works fine except that zenmode is not toggled on by default. When I open a notebook, I need to manually click on the zenmode button in order for the zenmode to be activated. This is not the case with another server which is run by a user who has write access to the environment. This is the only difference I can see in the two instances of jupyter servers running.

Any idea what could be wrong?

Thanks

items.title: code_prettify: option to disable js alert for unsupported kernels
items.body:
In [code_prettify/kernel_exec_on_cell.js](https://github.com/ipython-contrib/jupyter_contrib_nbextensions/blob/master/src/jupyter_contrib_nbextensions/nbextensions/code_prettify/kernel_exec_on_cell.js), there is an alert pop-up when the extension is loaded in a notebook that is not Python, R, or javascript; afterwards, the icon and keyboard shortcut is removed.  The alert shows up even when the option for "show alerts for errors in the kernel prettifying calls" is turned off.

Could a nbextension parameter please be included to handle that situation more "quietly", removing the icon and keyboard shortcut while not generating a js alert? 

Thank you.

items.title: maintenance status of jupyter_contrib_nbextensions?
items.body:
I am raising this "issue" in the hope of getting some response from the maintainers of `nbextensions` regarding the status and future of this repository. It has been 7 months since the last release - far longer than the previously longest interval between two successive releases - and there are no signs of activity. What is particularly concerning is that the recent `notebook` update (ver. 5.7) has made nbextensions (appear) incompatible and there seems to be little activity towards addressing this. 

Of course, I understand that the maintenance task is very time consuming and performed on a pure volunteering basis. I am sure I speak for everyone using (and enjoying) the extensions that your work is highly appreciated. Please consider establishing a donation mechanism so that we (the every day users) can support your hard work!

items.title: Why does python markdown uses pairs of curly brackets, not single curly brackets as in f-strings?
items.body:
Recently I have been working on a notebook to text converter (and back) at [Jupytext](https://github.com/mwouts/jupytext).

Today I got a very nice suggestion at https://github.com/spyder-ide/spyder/issues/7933: why don't I use f-strings to represent markdown cells?

I like the suggestion, but also I would like the converter to be compliant with python markdown extension. While I could implement, in the converter, a systematic replacement of `{a}` with `{{a}}`, and reversely, I'd like to be sure first that there's no option to support directly the f-string formating in markdown cells... Thanks!

items.title: navigation-hotkeys: please remove Esc toggle
items.body:
It took me a while to hunt this one down. This really useful navigation-hotkeys extension adds a problematic hotkey: `esc - toggle to edit mode`, which is already assigned to `switch to command mode`. This breaks a normal use flow where one would hit Esc to switch from any mode to Command mode followed by a custom command mode keyboard shortcut.

Once this extension is enabled `Esc` behavior becomes non-deterministic and if the current cell is not visible one can't tell the current mode - should I hit Esc or not? So for example I end up typing `ii` when I'm trying to interrupt the kernel, since hitting `Esc-ii` happened to be from an already 'command mode', and moving me into edit mode and entering 'ii' to the cell.

Please consider removing this shortcut or making it configurable on the user side. At the moment I have to disable this extension and manually re-insert all but one shortcut from it.

Thank you.

items.title: [Select CodeMirror Keymap] Feature request: A redo shortcut for Emacs keymap
items.body: I like and use the Emacs keymap a lot. What I miss is a 'redo' shortcut: somehow the Emacs keymap suppresses the existing 'redo' shortcut (i.e., Ctrl-Shift-Z or Cmd-Shift-Z) by the default keymap and does not provide an alternative. Under emacs one would press Ctrl-g and then press Ctrl-Shift-Minus to redo changes. This does not work with the Emacs keymap.

items.title: Identify Jupyter notebooks inside kernel.
items.body:
I had the problem that I wanted to identify notebooks [(link)](https://github.com/jupyter/notebook/issues/3820). I now found a [solution](https://github.com/adrianschneider94/notebook_id) which generates a UUID for each notebook and stores it in its metadata. When the notebook is loaded or the kernel restarted, this UUID is passed to the python kernel.

I guess that some other people would also like to identify their notebooks inside the kernel, for example to store notebook state data in a database. Thus I would like to contribute the extension to this repository.

Probably one should implement the same procedure for other kernels. I also haven't tested the extension on different versions of jupyter yet.

Best wishes,
Adrian Schneider

items.title: Installing the extensions breaks the installation of conda
items.body:
*Steps to reproduce:*

1. Install fresh Anaconda `Anaconda3-5.1.0-MacOSX-x86_64.sh`
2. After installation, run `conda update -n base conda` to update to `4.4.11`.
3. Install the extensions using: `conda install -c conda-forge jupyter_contrib_nbextensions`

At the end of step (3), the `conda` command is no longer available.

*Workaround:*

Swapping the order of steps (2) and (3) seems to solve the problem.

This is a very painful and broke my conda installation.

items.title: toc2 - Left margin not restored when toggling on/off the sidebar
items.body:
The margins are not restored when togging off the sidebar by pushing the toc button. 
This is due to the fact that function `toggle_toc`  in `toc2.js` fails [line 651](https://github.com/ipython-contrib/jupyter_contrib_nbextensions/blob/master/src/jupyter_contrib_nbextensions/nbextensions/toc2/toc2.js#L651) because `cfg` object is undefined.  Tentative fix follows.

items.title: Contributing - Add a section to README.md
items.body:
I wanted to [make an improvement](https://github.com/ipython-contrib/jupyter_contrib_nbextensions/issues/1223), but it took quite a while until I managed to setup a working development environment. A contributing section [like in Jupyterhubs repository](https://github.com/jupyterhub/jupyterhub#contributing) would have helped me!

Perhaps something like this could be added to the readme?

Contributing
============

1. __Fork__
2. __Clone and setup__
```bash
git clone https://github.com/ipython-contrib/jupyter_contrib_nbextensions.git
cd jupyter_contrib_nbextensions
pip install --editable .
jupyter-contrib-nbextension install --symlink --sys-prefix
```
3. __Develop__
4. __Pull request__

items.title: init_cell - Unnecessary dialog in untrusted notebooks without initialization cells
items.body:
Having the init_cell plugin enabled when opening an untrusted notebook will warn that it will not run the cells automatically, even though there are no initialization cells.

I provide my students with Jupyter through a JupyterHub and have added this extension by default as it could help me streamline distribution of material to them. My students will not know about this plugin, and I wan't to keep it that way unless there is a need for them to know about it.

I'll try make a PR fixing this as well as allowing them to run the code manually by clicking a button in the dialog.

items.title: Remove the wiki?
items.body: The wiki isn't used very much (basically the only meaningful edits in the last year have @benelot's in the last couple of days), and largely refers to things which don't exist any more, outdated things, or has outdated information. As a result, it's confusing, and I think mainly serves as a distraction from actual helpful stuff in the main repo, or at readthedocs. Maybe it's time to just get rid of the remainder of it? @juhasch @jfbercher thoughts?

items.title: Building a notebook extension that allows to register other cells as its execution dependencies
items.body:
Hello everyone,

I am thinking about writing an extension that allows for each cell to be annotated with cells on which its execution depends on. Working in a modular fashion could be simplified because it would allow to write short code segments that need to be run as initialization for others. For example, I can write a dataset download and extract section, which is then set as a dependency for a graph drawing cell. If I run the graph drawing cell, the dependent cells will be run before it to ensure its successful execution.

Can anybody give me some hints on where to start (what part of the doc I should read, not even sure if this is a front-end or back-end extension maybe both?) and how this could be done (as rough pseudocode like "you catch the event notification of the cell to be run and trigger all cells that are in its json tag called deps. The deps you can collect for each cell by inserting deps as special tags").

items.title: Does this package actually require a specific lxml version?
items.body:
In the setup.py, the version of lxml is tied to `>=3.8.0`.  I need to run jupyter_contrib_nbextensions on an embedded ARM computer where I built a kernel using [Yocto](https://yoctoproject.org/) and the version of Yocto I'm using only supplies lxml 3.6.4.  It's not trivial to build lxml 3.8+ on my PC.

Does this package really need lxml 3.8 or greater?  I cloned this repo and installed it after removing the version requirement, and everything installed correctly and all the tests passed.

I'm happy to submit a PR, but before I did I wanted to see if I was missing something.  If nbextensions really needs lxml >= 3.8, I'll just pin down the version of nbextensions in my own setup.py, but it'd be nice not to need to.

items.title: `python-markdown` renders incorrectly when sympy.init_printing() enabled
items.body:
If `sympy` is being used in a notebook with the `init_printing()` method enabled to support rendering of `sympy` elements, the [python-markdown](https://github.com/ipython-contrib/jupyter_contrib_nbextensions/tree/master/src/jupyter_contrib_nbextensions/nbextensions/python-markdown) extension breaks and an *end of line* is introduced before and after the substituted content.

```python
from sympy import init_printing
init_printing()

a=1.23
```

then in a markdown cell: `a is {{a}}, ok?` render as something like:

*a is*
*1.23*
*ok?*

with the *1.23* centered (presumably inherited from the `init_printing()` settings?).

items.title: [NbConvertApp] WARNING | Config option `codefolding` not recognized by `NbConvertApp`
Codefolding extension does not restore folding with nested expression
items.body:
Consider the following MWE:

```
# testsets
a = 2
def foo():
    pass
```
which appears, when the Codefolding extension is loaded, as:
![image 1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10957113/29276253-e0bdddf0-8105-11e7-9e19-8293e8c404c6.png)

- If I fold the code at the line `def foo():`, save and reload, I get the folding back as expected.
- If I fold the code at the first line, save and reload, I still get the folding back as expected.
- However, if I fold at the third line and then at the first line, save and reload, the folding is *not* restored.

Executing `IPython.notebook.get_cells()[0].metadata.code_folding` from the console, I do get what to me looks like what I should get when the code is folded at both positions:
![image 2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10957113/29276611-06a96894-8107-11e7-8fbe-91de102ae4d7.png)
I still get this when I reload the page and the code does not look folded, so I guess there is something wrong in the code that should restore the folding?

I see this on both Chrome and Opera under Windows 10, with the jupyter server run from bash on ubuntu on windows.
